docs.title: Webhook Failure Verdict
docs.text:
Webhook failures are high-frequency. This site helps engineers decide whether continuing to debug is worth it for common cases like:

  • webhook not triggered / not received
  • webhook timeout / delivery delayed
  • retry not working / duplicate delivery / out-of-order
  • signature invalid / secret mismatch
  • HTTP 400 / 401 / 403 / 404 / 410 / 500 / 502 / 503

This site does not teach step-by-step fixes or provide code snippets. It provides a decision-first verdict page for each failure mode.

This site exists because most webhook failures are decision problems, not implementation problems.

If you are searching for questions like:

  • "webhook not triggered but event exists"
  • "webhook retry not working"
  • "webhook timeout vs delayed delivery"
  • "webhook signature invalid"
  • "is this webhook failure worth debugging?"

This site provides verdict-oriented answers to decide whether continuing is justified, instead of step-by-step fixes.

Common searches include "webhook not triggered" and "webhook delivery failed"; this site is for deciding what to do next, not for implementation tutorials.

docs.title: Quick decision: what happened?
docs.text:
Pick the closest symptom:

  • Stripe signature verification failed / invalid signature
  • Webhook not triggered / not received → start with “not triggered” and “not received”.
  • Timeout / delivery delayed → start with “timeout” and “delivery delayed”.
  • HTTP status error (4xx/5xx) → use the matching HTTP page (400/401/403/404/410/500/502/503).

docs.title: FAQ
docs.text:
Is this a webhook debugging tutorial? No. This is a verdict site: it helps decide whether to keep debugging.

Does “valid signature” mean the event is correct? No. It only means the signature is cryptographically valid for that delivery.

Can I use this for any provider (not Stripe)? This site focuses on webhook failure patterns. The signature verifier tool is Stripe-specific.

It does not modify store data or change webhook behavior.

docs.title: Common false assumptions
docs.text:
• The issue must be inside your application code.
  • More debugging automatically increases certainty.
  • Sender claims are equivalent to independently verifiable delivery.

docs.title: Why debugging often goes wrong
docs.text: Time is spent optimizing or rewriting logic without confirming a ground-truth request and an observable delivery path.

docs.title: Responsibility boundaries
docs.text: Some parts of delivery, retry policy, and upstream evidence are owned by the sender or the network path before your infrastructure.

docs.title: When to stop debugging
docs.text: Stop when further debugging cannot increase certainty without new observable evidence.

docs.title: Link to verdict
docs.text: Webhook Failure Verdict

docs.title: Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: STOP debugging. This is not a transient webhook error. It indicates an authorization boundary mismatch.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: A 401 response means the receiving endpoint rejected the request at the authentication layer. This is not about delivery reliability, retries, or payload correctness.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Retrying does not change authorization state. More logs do not alter credentials. Time invested here rarely increases certainty.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: Authorization rules are enforced by the receiving system. If you do not control that system, this failure is outside your responsibility.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text:
• Verified credential rotation acknowledged by the receiver
  • Explicit confirmation that the auth layer accepts this webhook identity

Without this, continuing is unjustified.

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text:
If Stripe is involved, signature validity must be verified independently.

Use the verifier: https://webhookverdict.com/tools/stripe-webhook-signature-verifier/

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: STOP. Do not continue debugging unless authorization ownership is restored.

docs.text: Webhook Failure Verdict

docs.title: Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: STOP waiting for retries to fix this. A 502 indicates upstream instability, not webhook misconfiguration.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: A 502 response is generated by an intermediary or upstream service. Webhook delivery succeeded; processing did not.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Retrying only re-enters an unstable upstream path. No amount of webhook tuning stabilizes a failing dependency.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: Upstream availability is not controlled by the webhook sender. This failure lies outside webhook ownership.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text:
• Upstream provider confirms incident resolution
  • Verified stable processing independent of webhook retries

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text: There is no deterministic webhook-side verification for upstream failures.

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: STOP. Do not treat this as a webhook problem.

docs.title: Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: STOP treating delay as failure.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: Webhook delivery latency fluctuates due to queueing and backoff. This does not indicate loss.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Latency is not deterministic. Debugging does not shorten queues.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: Delivery scheduling is owned by the sender platform.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text: • Explicit confirmation of permanent delivery failure

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text: Delivery delay has no deterministic verification.

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: STOP.

docs.title: Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: STOP treating duplicates as delivery errors.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: Webhook systems guarantee at-least-once delivery. Duplicates are expected behavior.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Delivery logic is correct. Absence of idempotency creates false failure perception.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: Idempotency is the receiver's responsibility.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text: • Verified idempotent handling at the receiver

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text: No webhook-side verification exists for idempotency correctness.

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: STOP.

docs.title: Webhook Not Received – Delivery Boundary Verdict
Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: CONDITIONAL. Continue only if delivery evidence is missing.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: Non-receipt may indicate routing, endpoint, or configuration errors. It may also be perception caused by delay.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Without delivery evidence, guessing is ineffective.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: Delivery proof is owned by the sender platform.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text: • Sender-side delivery logs confirming failure

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text: Use sender-side delivery logs only.

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: CONDITIONAL.

docs.title: Webhook Not Triggered – Event Generation Verdict
Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: STOP treating this as a webhook problem.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: If no event is generated, no webhook can fire. This precedes delivery.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Webhook infrastructure cannot deliver nonexistent events.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: Event generation is owned by the sender system.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text: • Verified event generation at source

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text: Check event existence, not webhook delivery.

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: STOP.

docs.title: Webhook Retry Not Working – Retry Exhaustion Verdict
Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: STOP relying on retries. Retries do not fix structural processing failures.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: Retries only repeat the same failing execution path. They do not alter system state or dependencies.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Retry loops create noise, not information. Certainty does not increase after initial failure.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: The receiving system must become stable. Retry policy is not a corrective mechanism.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text: • Independent confirmation that processing logic is fixed

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text: None. Retries are probabilistic, not deterministic.

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: STOP.

docs.title: Webhook Secret Mismatch – Signature Failure Verdict
Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: CONTINUE only if signature verification fails. Otherwise, STOP investigating secrets.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: Webhook signatures fail when the signing secret does not match the expected value or when the raw request body has been altered.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Guessing secrets or re-copying values does not increase certainty. Only cryptographic verification resolves this.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: Secret correctness is a shared boundary. Payload integrity is the receiver's responsibility.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text: • Deterministic cryptographic verification result

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text: Use the Stripe signature verifier: https://webhookverdict.com/tools/stripe-webhook-signature-verifier/

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: CONDITIONAL. Continue only with verified cryptographic evidence.

docs.title: Verdict (TL;DR)
docs.text: STOP retry-based debugging. Timeouts indicate processing constraints, not delivery failure.

docs.title: Why this happens (structural)
docs.text: The webhook reached the endpoint, but processing exceeded allowed time. Delivery is complete; execution is not.

docs.title: Why further debugging often fails
docs.text: Increasing retries increases load without reducing execution time. Timeouts persist until processing constraints change.

docs.title: Responsibility boundary
docs.text: Execution time is owned by the receiving system. The webhook sender is not responsible.

docs.title: What evidence would change this verdict
docs.text: • Verified processing time reduced below timeout threshold

docs.title: Deterministic verification
docs.text: No webhook-level verification exists for execution duration.

docs.title: Final decision
docs.text: STOP.

docs.title: When to use this tool
docs.text:
Use this tool if Stripe webhook signature verification fails and you need a definitive verdict.

When NOT to use this tool ## When NOT to use this tool Do NOT use this tool if you are debugging application code, validating business logic, or replaying webhooks.

docs.title: Common failure reasons
docs.text:
• Verification ID expired
  • Verification ID does not belong to this endpoint
  • Webhook was never successfully delivered
Why this tool exists ## Why this tool exists Stripe webhook signature verification is a high-frequency failure point in real systems. Most failures are not caused by Stripe sending an invalid request, but by **intermediate handling that changes the original request bytes**. Common causes (facts only): - **Raw body not preserved**: payload is reconstructed from a parsed object, re-stringified, trimmed, normalized, or has newline differences. - **JSON parsing happens before verification**: middleware consumes/decodes the body; the bytes used for verification are not identical. - **Wrong webhook secret**: secret from another endpoint, wrong environment (test vs live), or an outdated/rotated value. - **Wrong attempt/context**: mixing data across deliveries/environments/endpoints results in a failed verification.

docs.title: Compatible with Stripe Webhook Signing
docs.text: Compatibility notes: checks the Stripe-Signature header format, uses timestamp tolerance semantics, and matches Stripe’s official signing algorithm for webhook signatures.

docs.title: What is being verified (and what is not)
docs.text:
Verified: Given a verification_id (generated when Stripe delivers a webhook to this tool) and your webhook signing secret (whsec_...), the tool decides whether Stripe produced a valid signature for that specific delivery.

Not verified:

  • Business correctness
  • Whether the event “should” occur
  • Whether application code is implemented correctly

This is a one-time decision about signature validity only. It does not replay or process the event.

docs.title: Webhook Secret: origin and confidentiality boundary
docs.text:
The webhook secret is generated in the Stripe Dashboard when a webhook endpoint is created. Each endpoint has its own fixed secret (until rotated). This tool assumes that secret is already available.

The secret is sensitive and is not intended to be exposed to third-party services. You provide it voluntarily for a single verification request, and it is used only to compute a verdict for the referenced delivery.

docs.title: Why verification can fail even when the event is 100% from Stripe
docs.text:
Legitimate source does not imply verifiable signature. Signature verification operates on bytes, not on “equivalent JSON.” Any middle layer that changes the payload byte stream (re-encoding, newline normalization, trimming, or re-serialization) can keep the meaning but break verification.

Input: Verification ID, webhook signing secret Output: Valid / Invalid Stripe webhook signature

docs.title: Stripe Webhook Signature Verification FAQ
docs.text:
How do I verify a Stripe webhook signature?

Verify Stripe webhook signature by submitting the webhook delivery reference (verification_id) and the corresponding webhook signing secret (whsec_...) to obtain a definitive Stripe signature verdict for that specific delivery.

Can I use this tool without reading other pages?

Yes. This is a standalone online stripe webhook signature verifier page: you can verify stripe webhook signature online here and only use the related pages if you want context for common failure modes.

Why does signature verification fail even with the correct secret?

Most failures are caused by mixing contexts (wrong endpoint, wrong environment, or using a verification ID from a different delivery) or using the wrong signing secret. Verification is specific to one delivery and one secret.

What is a verification ID?

A verification ID identifies a specific webhook delivery that Stripe sent to this tool. Use it to request a signature verdict for that single delivery.

What does verification_id not found mean?

This indicates an expired or unknown webhook delivery reference (for example: the verification ID expired, belongs to a different endpoint/environment, or the webhook was never successfully delivered). It is not a system error.

Is the signing secret stored or cached?

No. It is used for one verification request and is not stored or cached by this page.

Does a valid signature mean the event data is safe to trust?

A valid signature confirms that the provided inputs (verification ID + secret) correspond to a valid Stripe signature for that delivery. It does not certify business correctness, expectedness of the event, or downstream handling.

Tool positioning summary ## Tool positioning summary This is a tool for **assigning problem ownership**: it distinguishes “signature is mathematically invalid for these inputs” from “application-level decisions.” It fits scenarios where a webhook delivery has already been received and a signature verdict is needed for that specific delivery; it does not fit scenarios where the goal is to judge business meaning or whether an event should be accepted.

docs.title: Webhook Failure Verdict
docs.text: This page provides a decision-oriented verdict only. It does not offer fixes or implementation guidance.

docs.title: When continuing to debug is likely justified
docs.text:
• You can consistently observe inbound requests.
  • Failures occur after the request reaches your system.
  • The issue is reproducible under controlled conditions.

docs.title: When continuing to debug is unlikely to help
docs.text:
• No inbound request reaches your infrastructure.
  • Delivery evidence cannot be independently verified.
  • The failure depends on external systems you do not control.

docs.title: High uncertainty / stop-risk
docs.text:
• You cannot obtain a ground-truth request.
  • Logs or claims from the sender are inconsistent.
  • Further debugging only increases sunk cost.

Verdict framing you can reuse:

  • “Continuing to debug is unlikely to help without a confirmed inbound request.”
  • “This failure is commonly external or non-actionable at the application layer.”
